paragraphs.text: Immigration: Congress must reassert its authority and preserve our Constitution.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: It's unconstitutional
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It's reckless
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It's lawless
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: All these things have been said about President Obama's executive action on immigration--a breathtaking order that not only changes laws passed by Congress, but will likely send millions of mostly low-skill workers flooding into a workplace that is already struggling to raise wages and find room for all those needing jobs
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Immigration is a remarkably complex subject, and not just as a matter of policy
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Our nation's immigration laws can be difficult to understand
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Our Constitution, however, isn't complicated
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Our system of government is simple
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Congress writes the law
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: the president executes the law
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the judiciary interprets the law
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: The president does not make new law
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: That concept is called the "separation of powers,"
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it's of core importance to our democracy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As a bulwark against tyranny, our Founders determined that no single branch of government could perform all the functions of government-- making, enforcing, and interpreting the law
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: In other words
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: our Founders took the classic powers of a king and divided them between the legislative, executive, and judicial branches
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: For our government to work, those functions must remain separate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But President Obama disagrees with the Founders
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In his view, apparently, government is only truly "working" when he gets the policies he wants
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: When he doesn't, he calls that "obstructionism" and gets busy finding workarounds to democracy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: While presidents do have a degree of discretion in determining exactly how to enforce the law
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: President Obama's immigration actions go far, far beyond that lawful discretion and veer directly into lawmaking, the exclusive role of the legislature
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Here's how
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: President Obama is taking action in direct defiance to Congress's "expressed or implied intent,"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that means his power--constitutionally--is at its "lowest ebb."
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Supreme Court Justice Robert Jackson, in the seminal case of Youngstown Sheet & Tube Co  v  Sawyer, outlined an influential three-part test for executive action
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Presidential power is "at its maximum" when acting pursuant to congressional authorization
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: There is a "zone of twilight" when the distribution of power between Congress and the president is uncertain
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Then
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: there's the "lowest ebb," when the president defies Congress
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: That's exactly what President Obama did
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Article I of the Constitution grants Congress -- not the president -- the power to "establish a uniform Rule of Naturalizations,"
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Congress has acted under that power to write and pass a comprehensive set of immigration statutes
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Many people disagree with those laws
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: President Obama is particularly dissatisfied
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they are still the law
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: And the president certainly can't hide behind "prosecutorial discretion."
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Office of Legal Counsel (OLC) --the government lawyers President Obama asked to evaluate his proposed program-- were clear, declaring that the president cannot "under the guise of exercising enforcement discretion, attempt to effectively rewrite the laws to match its policy preference."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Thus
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: as the Secretary of Homeland Security said,"As an act of prosecutorial discretion, deferred action is legally available so long as it is granted on a case-by-case basis, and it may be terminated at any time at the agency's discretion."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: did President Obama promise a "case-by-case" determination
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: or
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: did he make a sweeping promise to millions of illegal immigrants?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He didn't promise them a careful review
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: he promised them a deal
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Here are his words
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: So we're going to offer the following deal: If you've with been in America more than five years. If you have children who are American citizens or illegal residents. If you register, pass a criminal background check and you're willing to pay your fair share of taxes, you'll be able to apply to stay in this country temporarily without fear of deportation
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: . You can come out of the shadows and get right with the law. That's what this deal is
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Tuesday, I am testifying before the House Judiciary Committee
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I am examining the "deal" President Obama offers and compare it with the requirements of the law -- the requirement of a case-by-case review
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The "deal" does not match the law
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Put simply
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: if
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: President Obama is enacting the "case-by-case" review mandated by the OLC memo
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: he is misleading the four million illegal aliens he encouraged to come "out of the shadows."
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: he is defying the attorneys at the OLC and giving illegal aliens the "deal" he promised
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: then he is misleading the American public
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: No one disputes that our nation faces an immigration challenge
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We've got a porous, dangerous border, a flood of illegal immigrants whose increasing numbers drive down wages and can overburden social services
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: we've got millions of people in the country who are looking for some form of permanent status
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: No one doubts that legislative reform is necessary
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I believe we need comprehensive immigration reform beginning with securing our borders
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: We truly are a nation of immigrants
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: I am the grandson of a Russian immigrant
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But that reform must be done lawfully and in accordance with the Constitution
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The bottom line
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: impatient presidents may not violate the Constitution if they don't get their way
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: In doing so-- in circumventing Congress to change the law-- President Obama has set a dangerous precedent
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Congress must reassert its authority and preserve our Constitution
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Our democracy is at stake
paragraphs.label: assumption
